section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials Alphabet Cards for Ww and Yy, one yellow paper circle per child, drawing paper folded in half, crayons

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we read the story Everybunny Dance! We saw the letter y and the letter w in some of the words.
This is uppercase W and this is lowercase w. The letter w makes the /w/ sound you hear in the words Wagon and wolf.
This is uppercase Y and this is lowercase y. The letter y makes the /y/ sound you hear at the beginning of the words Yo-yo and yarn.
Today we will play a listening game. Then we will make some pictures to help us remember the sounds.
Listen. The word wiggle begins with the /w/ sound.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Say If you hear a word that begins like wiggle, wiggle your fingers. Say the following words: water, window, wind, sit, wolf, go, and wire.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Listen. The word yellow begins with the /y/ sound.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Say If you hear a word that begins like yellow, hold up your yellow circle. Say the following words and wait for a response: you, yes, yard, cat, yak, sun, and yo-yo.
Draw Give children drawing paper folded in half. Invite them to draw a wiggly worm on one side and a yellow yo-yo on the other side. Help children label their drawings.
Writing Letters Yy, Ww Children may enjoy tracing over dotted letters, writing letters in the air, or making letters in a sand or salt tray.

Children may need support when listening for a sound. Instead of asking them to wiggle their fingers or hold up the yellow circle when they hear a word with the target sound, give each child a letter card to hold and show (w first, and then y) when you do the activity.

For children who need a challenge, follow the first listening activity with one that is led by a child. Choose a child to lead and call out a word that begins with /w/ or /y/. Invite the other children to respond by wiggling their fingers or raising the yellow circle.

Be aware that children whose first language is Spanish may know the long e sound for Yy, but not the /y/ sound that begins yo-yo and yarn. Take time, as needed, to review the sound for Yy as /y/ at the beginning

Children with auditory discrimination challenges may have trouble distinguishing the sounds for Ww and Yy. Exaggerate the movements of your mouth as you form each letter sound, emphasizing the sounds. Do this as you say the sound in isolation and again as you say the sound within the picture word. Invite children to move their mouths in the same way as you repeat each letter sound.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we read the story Everybunny Dance! We enjoyed seeing the bunnies dance.
We learned about making connections. We learned that when you make a connection you take something you learned in one place and use it in another place.

We saw that the bunnies used different steps when they danced. Today we will use different steps to make up a dance. First we will look at some steps and do them. Then we will choose three to do in a row and dance!

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Set Up To introduce choices for the dance, show one Activity Card at the time. Go through the questioning on the back of the card.
Choose Display the cards face up. Ask three children to each pick a card. Remove the other cards and set the cards in a row so that children can see the steps to do for the dance.
Perform Invite children to look at the cards and do the steps in order to make the dance.
Repeat Repeat the activity so that several children have a chance to choose the steps.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we used what we saw the bunnies do in the story and used our own steps to make up dances. What other things that you read about in the story might you want to do?

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: When you present the Activity Cards, you may want to limit the number, so that there are only four cards. Then you might want to limit the number of things for the dance to only two.
Invite children to make up their own steps, without using the cards, practice them, and perform them for the other children.

Add to children’s growing English vocabularies by naming the actions shown on the cards as they proceed in making up the dance. You might also extend the learning by talking about the body parts used. For example, “I use my hands to clap,” or “I use my feet to stomp.”

Sequencing activities may be difficult for children with attention challenges. The activity gets particularly challenging when children need to remember a sequence of steps to follow without visual support. Make sure you refer them to the cards, so they don’t lose their places.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Prepare Ahead paper plate masks for a fox, dog, and cat—each labeled with its name
Gather Materials paper plates; scissors; cut-outs of ears for fox, dog, and cat; crayons; glue

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we read the story Everybunny Dance! In that story there was a fox. The word fox is a word made up of three sounds. We can put the sounds together to say the whole word. Listen: /f/-/o/ /ks/, fox. The word is fox.

Here are three animal masks. I will name all the sounds for each animal. Then we’ll put all the sounds together to say the name of the animal that is printed on the mask. After, you will choose which animal mask you want to make.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Set Up Show the animal masks as you blend the sounds to make each animal name.
Say Let’s put the sounds together to say the whole word. Listen: /d//o/ /g/, dog. What’s the word? The word is dog. Point to the dog mask.
Repeat Repeat with the sounds of dog, cat, and fox.

Writing Invite children to label their own mask. Help them write the letter that names the first sound of the animal name and any other letters they can. Have them share and appreciate each other’s work.

Blending phonemes may be difficult. Model saying the phonemes in a word very slowly and distinctly. Have children repeat each phoneme after you. Then have them blend the phonemes to say the word with you.
Show children a picture or object with a single-syllable name. Challenge children to identify the separate phonemes in the word and then blend the phonemes to say the word.

Picture support and repeated practice help to support multilingual learners in acquiring new vocabulary and speaking a new language. Some sounds in English that do not exist in other languages may be challenging for children. Follow the speech support below. Make note of phonemes that are difficult for children. Come back to the exercise periodically to help children practice blending words with challenging phonemes.

Practicing blending phonemes can be beneficial for children with speech challenges. Help children practice the phonemes slowly. If they have difficulty pronouncing a particular phoneme, show them how you move your lips and tongue to say the sound.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials index cards, each printed with a word: goat, coat, duck, truck, chick, stick, cat, hat, dog and log

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we sang about Old MacDonald’s Farm. As you know, the animals on the farm love to make their animal sounds. But did you know they also love to say words that rhyme? They do!

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Explain the Activity Let’s pretend we are the farm animals and say these rhyming pairs. I’ll say them first, and then you repeat them. Turn over the pairs of rhyming words, one pair at a time, and say them: goat, coat, duck, truck, chick, stick, cat, hat, dog, and log. Illustrate each word with a simple outline and say each word again.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Now let’s use the rhyming pairs to play a memory game. I will place the cards face down. When it’s your chance, turn over two cards, say the words, and decide if the words rhyme. If the words rhyme, keep the rhyming pair.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Ask Invite a child to choose a pair of cards. Help her read the words and then ask if the words rhyme.
Repeat Repeat until all the pairs are matched.

Talk About Rhymes Say the following words from the book Everybunny Dance! Ask children to clap two times if the words rhyme: ready/steady; twirl/whirl; shake/wiggle; flute/toot; pirouette/clarinet; clap/jump and sigh/eye.
To simplify the activity, point to the pictures when a child turns over the cards. Ask, Does goat rhyme with coat? Then help the child answer, “Yes! Goat and coat rhyme.”
Invite children to name other words that could be added to each rhyming pair. Note which sounds have the most and fewest additional rhymes.
Help multilingual learners identify the pictures and words. Rhyming helps children playfully manipulate sounds. Phonemic awareness lays the groundwork for written language.

Incorporating more physical movement into the activity may benefit children with attention challenges. Display the cards, and invite children to walk up and point to the correct picture as they act out the meaning in addition to saying it.
